newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bond prices continue up, boosted by Bund.
newsitem.headline: Danish bond prices continue up, boosted by Bund.

text.p: Danish bond prices continued to build on their earlier gains on Thursday, lifted intitially by Wednesday's U.S. advances, then boosted further by rises in German Bund futures.
"It is a suprisingly positive market, but I imagine that we have reached the day's peak," a dealer said.
At 1040 GMT the benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was up 0.50 point from Wednesday's close, at 110.20, yielding 6.45 percent, in turnover of 1.8 billion crowns.
Its June future rose 0.50 point to 109.70, with 111 contracts traded.
The six percent mortgage bond due 2026 gained 0.30 point to 88.15.
The crown traded unchanged at 3.8060 per mark.
The 10-year yield gap with Germany widened to 66 basis points, from Wednesday's 63 b.p.

The Central Bank was active on the market, selling around 700 million crowns worth of the 7 percent bond due 2024 and the 5 percent 2005 paper, as part of its routine financing operations. --Stig Pedersen, Copenhagen newsroom, 45-33-969659
